title: NYT Claims More Gun Laws In U.K. Equals Less Political Violence, Immediately Shown Wrong…
text:
Are seriously restricted gun laws the key to suffering only rare large-scale terrorist attacks? 
Not so, according to writer Matthew Balan. 
Writing for Mediaite, Balan shares a tweet that points out an attack that the Times may have overlooked: You sure about that? https://t.co/w3AJJ5RLx9 pic.twitter.com/9EAozkPIG3 googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('div-gpt-ad-1481811813211-2'); });

Balan adds: 
There was a much more recent attack on a member of the British Parliament than the 1979 incident cited by Bennhold and Castle. MP Jo Cox was stabbed and shot to death in June 2016 by a white supremacist. 
The two Times reporters also neglected the decades-long campaign by the Provisional IRA against the British government. The nationalist terrorist group conducted major terrorist attacks in Britain in 1982, 1984 (where they tried to assassinate Margaret Thatcher), and 1989. The organization also conducted bombings in the 1990s until the Good Friday Agreement in 1998. 
So perhaps the rarity of British political violence has been overstated. And perhaps the role of guns in perpetrating political violence has been as well. 
In Townhall, columnist Matt Vespa adds: 
What does gun ownership have to do with an attack that involved a motor vehicle and a knife? Moreover, firearms and explosives were definitely used during The Troubles. It was just an anti-gun cheap shot. 
Perhaps the most recent event that rebuts the New York Times report about the lack of political violence in the UK because of its gun laws is the tragic case of British soldier Lee Rigby. 
Returning to his base in London, Rigby was struck behind by an automobile by radical Islamists, who then killed him while attempting to decapitate him. It was a horrific death for an Afghan war veteran.
